flow.context: Hana Tomita is on the vacation rentals team at Keys Vacation Rentals (BHHS Keys Real Estate, Knight & Gardner Realty) in Key West. She started her own full-service property management and cleaning company before joining — she lives and breathes turnover operations and knows what it takes to keep units guest-ready. They run on Guesty (migrated from LiveRez) for PMS and booking. Senior decision-makers above her are Claude Gardner (Broker/Partner) and Will Langley (CEO-level). Strongest personal hook: Hana's bio mentions the island lifestyle — beach and kayaking — which connects to Sam's surfing and fishing background.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Hana — this is gonna sound a little random, but I saw your profile and noticed you're big into the island life out there, the kayaking and everything. I'm a surfer myself — actually just got back from a trip. I work with a few vacation rental managers down in the Keys on their turnover workflows. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Relaxed tone. Feet up on the desk energy. Don't rush through the intro — let the island lifestyle comment land before moving to the name drop. Smile while you say it.

branches.label: No, I haven't heard of you
Who is this? / What's this about?

no_havent_heard.label: NOT AS POPULAR
no_havent_heard.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well hey, the reason I'm calling — I've been working with another property manager down in the Keys who's in a pretty similar spot to you guys. She was telling me that after every turnover, her cleaners are snapping like forty, fifty photos per unit, uploading them into Guesty, and then… nobody actually has time to look through all of them. Stuff gets missed — a stain on a couch, a cracked tile, a missing set of towels — and it doesn't surface until the next guest checks in and leaves a bad review. We built a tool that plugs right into Guesty and automatically flags damage and missing items from the photos your cleaners are already taking. No workflow change on their end. Would you be open to seeing what that looks like — not right now obviously, but when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
no_havent_heard.note: Pause after 'leaves a bad review.' Let the pain sink in. The Guesty mention shows you did homework. Don't oversell the solution — one sentence and move to the CTA.

branches.label: We already have a process for that
I'm not the right person for this

yes_heard.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
yes_heard.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you on this. What'd you hear?
yes_heard.note: Let them talk. Whatever they say, agree and bridge into the pain trigger or discovery. Don't correct them — build on whatever they give you.

clarify_and_pain.label: CLARIFY AND BRIDGE TO PAIN
clarify_and_pain.say: Ah no worries — so what we do is pretty specific. I work with vacation rental managers who are already collecting turnover photos — in your case through Guesty — and we automatically analyze those photos for damage, missing items, staging issues. The reason I wanted to reach out to you specifically is because of your cleaning and PM background — I figured if anyone on the Keys team would get the pain of trying to catch everything between turnovers, it'd be you. Is that fair?
clarify_and_pain.note: Acknowledge her expertise. You're not teaching her the problem — you're validating she already knows it.

branches.label: Yeah that's definitely a pain point
We handle it fine / not a big issue
I'm not really the one who decides on tools

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow, maybe late morning?
bad_timing.note: Offer a specific time. Don't be vague. If they push back on tomorrow, offer later in the week.

lock_callback.label: LOCK THE CALLBACK
lock_callback.say: Perfect — I've got tomorrow at 11 pulled up. Does that work, or is there a better window? I'll shoot you a quick text so you have my number.
lock_callback.note: Get a specific time committed. Send a text immediately after hanging up so your number is saved in her phone.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — it is a cold call, I'll be straight with you. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out, and you can totally hang up on me if it doesn't make sense?
permission_fallback.note: Disarming honesty. Most people will give you 30 seconds if you ask like this. Keep your voice calm and unbothered.

pain_trigger_short.label: 30-SECOND PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger_short.say: Appreciate it. So I've been working with a few vacation rental managers in the Keys, and the thing I keep hearing is — cleaners are taking photos every turnover, uploading them into the PMS, but nobody actually has bandwidth to review them all. Stuff slips through — a broken drawer handle, a stain, missing patio cushions — and it shows up as a guest complaint or a bad review. We built something that automatically catches that stuff from the photos your team's already taking. Plugs right into Guesty. Would you be open to seeing what it looks like sometime this week?
pain_trigger_short.note: This is your compressed pitch. Hit the pain, the solution, and the CTA in 30 seconds flat. Then pause and let her respond.

branches.label: We already handle that pretty well

rejection_split.label: REJECTION SPLIT
rejection_split.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and it's just not a fit?
rejection_split.note: Split the rejection. You're giving them a way to say 'bad timing' without losing face. Most will pick that option.

branches.label: It's not a fit / not interested

warm_discovery.label: DISCOVERY — THEY'RE WARM
warm_discovery.say: Awesome. So I know you come from a cleaning and PM background — you probably have a better handle on this than most. Can I ask — what does your turnover inspection process look like right now? Like after a cleaner finishes a unit, are they taking photos into Guesty, or is it more of a checklist situation?
warm_discovery.note: STOP PITCHING. You're in discovery mode now. Let her talk. Take notes. The more she describes her current process, the more ammunition you have.

branches.label: Says they don't really have a formal process
Deflects / asks what we do first

discovery_guesty_deep.label: GUESTY PHOTO WORKFLOW
discovery_guesty_deep.say: Got it — so the photos are going into Guesty already. That's actually exactly what we plug into. Quick question — when those photos come in, who's reviewing them? Is it you, or is there someone else looking through them before the next guest checks in?
discovery_guesty_deep.note: You're mapping their workflow. Find out where the bottleneck is — is it that nobody reviews, or that the review is too slow, or that things still slip through despite review?

branches.label: I review them / we try to review
Our cleaners handle it on their own

discovery_manual.label: MANUAL / CHECKLIST PROCESS
discovery_manual.say: Makes sense. And when something does get missed — like a stain or a broken item — how does that typically surface? Is it usually a guest complaint, or do you catch it on the next turnover?
discovery_manual.note: You're looking for the consequence of their current process. Let her tell you about the pain in her own words.

branches.label: We catch most stuff on the next turn

discovery_no_process.label: NO FORMAL PROCESS
discovery_no_process.say: That's honestly pretty common — especially when you're running turnovers back to back in peak season down there. Is that something you've been wanting to tighten up, or has it not been a big enough pain point yet?
discovery_no_process.note: Don't judge. Acknowledge it's common. See if there's latent demand or if this is a non-issue for them.

branches.label: Yeah we've been wanting to fix that
It hasn't been a huge issue

pain_deepener.label: DEEPEN THE PAIN
pain_deepener.say: Yeah — that's exactly what I keep hearing. And down in the Keys especially, with the salt air and the humidity, small stuff turns into expensive stuff fast. One PM I work with told me she had a guest ding her with a one-star review over a mildew spot on patio furniture that her cleaner photographed but nobody caught in the photos. Cost her a booking the next week. How many units are you guys turning over in a typical week right now?
pain_deepener.note: The salt air and humidity detail is Key West-specific and shows you understand her market. The story makes it visceral. Then pivot to sizing the opportunity with the volume question.

branches.label: Asks more about what we do
Says it's not that many / we're small

soft_challenge.label: SOFT CHALLENGE
soft_challenge.say: Totally fair. Out of curiosity — when's the last time something slipped through that you wish you'd caught earlier? Even something small.
soft_challenge.note: Everyone has a story. This question forces recall of a specific moment. If she has one, she'll start selling herself on the problem.

branches.label: Tells a story / gives an example
Can't think of one / we're really on top of it

solution_drop.label: SOLUTION DROP
solution_drop.say: So here's what we built — RapidEye plugs into Guesty, pulls the photos your cleaners are already uploading after every turnover, and automatically flags anything off. Damage, missing items, staging that doesn't match the listing photos. No extra work for your cleaners, no extra app, nothing changes for them. You just get a report that says hey, unit 4 has a stain on the living room couch and the patio umbrella is missing. Would you be open to seeing it in action? I could walk you through a quick demo — 15 minutes, tops.
solution_drop.note: One clear explanation. Reference Guesty by name. Emphasize zero workflow change. Then CTA with a specific time commitment. Pause after the question.

branches.label: I'd need to check with someone else first
We don't have budget for something like this

solution_drop_small.label: SOLUTION DROP — SMALLER OPERATION
solution_drop_small.say: Got it — and honestly, that's where this is even more valuable. When you're running a tighter operation, every bad review and every missed damage claim hits harder. What we do is plug into Guesty and automatically flag issues from the photos your cleaners are already taking. No extra work, no extra apps. Would it make sense to take a quick look? Even if it's just to see what other PMs in the Keys market are doing — worst case you steal some ideas.
solution_drop_small.note: Reframe smaller scale as higher stakes per unit. The 'steal some ideas' line lowers the commitment bar significantly.

branches.label: I'd need to loop someone else in

offer_of_value.label: OFFER OF VALUE
offer_of_value.say: Totally respect that. Here's what I'd offer though — even if this isn't something you need right now, I could walk you through what some of the other PM companies in Key West are doing with their turnover photos. Some are using Breezeway, some are doing it through their PMS directly — there's some interesting stuff happening. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends. Would that be worth 15 minutes?
offer_of_value.note: You're selling the meeting as valuable even if they never buy. Position yourself as a peer sharing market intel, not a vendor pitching a product.

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with your background starting your own cleaning and PM company, I'd honestly be surprised if you didn't have something solid in place. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that you're fully covered and happy with how inspections are working, or is it more that switching anything right now would just be a headache?
objection_have_process.note: Agree first. Compliment her expertise genuinely. Then split the objection. Most people will admit their process isn't perfect when you give them a safe way to say it.

branches.label: We're happy with what we have
It's more that switching would be a pain

objection_happy_vendor.label: THEY'RE HAPPY WITH CURRENT PROCESS
objection_happy_vendor.say: Love that — honestly that's rare. Mind if I ask what you're using? I'm always curious how different teams are handling it, especially in the Keys market.
objection_happy_vendor.note: Genuine curiosity. If she names a tool, you learn competitive intel. If she describes a manual process, there's still an opening. Either way you keep the conversation going.

branches.label: Names a specific tool or vendor
Describes a manual or in-house process

acknowledge_and_differentiate.label: ACKNOWLEDGE AND DIFFERENTIATE
acknowledge_and_differentiate.say: That's smart. The thing we do differently is we're not another task management layer — we're actually analyzing the photos themselves with AI. So if your cleaner snaps 40 photos after a turnover, our system looks at every single one and flags anything that's off compared to the baseline. It catches stuff humans miss because nobody has time to zoom into every photo. But look — you're in a good spot and I don't want to mess with what's working. Would it be worth seeing a side-by-side sometime, just so you know what's out there? No pressure at all.
acknowledge_and_differentiate.note: Position RapidEye as complementary, not competitive. The side-by-side framing is low threat. Don't trash their current process.

branches.label: Yeah I'd be curious to see that

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it — I should've assumed you'd be all set. Otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that turnover inspections aren't really a pain point for you, or is it more that you just hate cold calls? Because honestly I get it either way.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree. Don't push. Split the objection with humor. The cold call admission is disarming and makes you human.

branches.label: It's more the cold call thing
It's genuinely not a priority for us

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone buy something new — especially under the Berkshire umbrella where I'm sure everything goes through approvals. Just so nobody from my team bugs you — is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything you try to buy puts you through the ringer?
objection_no_budget.note: The Berkshire Hathaway reference shows you understand their corporate structure and the approval friction that comes with it. Split the objection to keep the conversation alive.

branches.label: Budget is locked / can't buy anything right now

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Makes total sense. You're probably not buying anything right now, and I totally respect that. But here's what I've seen — when budget does free up or the timing's right, the people who move fastest are the ones who already know what's one, two, three on their list. Would you be open to just seeing what it looks like? Fifteen minutes, no commitment. Worst case you see what other PMs in the Keys are doing and steal some ideas.
sell_test_drive.note: You're not asking them to buy. You're asking them to get informed. The 'steal some ideas' line lowers the bar to almost nothing.

branches.label: Alright, let's do a quick look

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL — NOT THE RIGHT PERSON
referral_ask.say: Totally fair — who on your team would typically own something like this? Like who's the person making decisions on inspection or turnover workflows?
referral_ask.note: You're looking for Claude Gardner (Broker/Partner) or Will Langley (CEO-level) or possibly Becky Cobo (most experienced PM). Let her name them — don't lead with a name yet.

branches.label: Not sure / it's kind of shared
That would be me but I'm not interested

referral_get_details.label: GET REFERRAL DETAILS
referral_get_details.say: Perfect — if I can get their best number or email, I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands and doesn't look like a generic cold pitch. Would you mind sharing their direct line, or should I just reach out through the main office number?
referral_get_details.note: Ask for direct contact info. If she gives a name you already have researched, great — but getting the warm intro or permission to name-drop Hana is gold.

branches.label: Says to just call the office
Offers to pass along a message for you

referral_probe_deeper.label: PROBE FOR THE RIGHT PERSON
referral_probe_deeper.say: Got it — so if you guys were gonna add a tool to your turnover workflow, who would sign off on that? Would that be Claude or someone else on the leadership side?
referral_probe_deeper.note: Drop Claude Gardner's name casually. If she confirms, you have your next call target with a warm reference. If she corrects you, even better — you learn the real decision-maker.

referral_close.label: CLOSE THE REFERRAL
referral_close.say: Really appreciate that, Hana. I'll reach out to them and mention we chatted — I won't make it weird, I promise. And hey, if you ever want to see what we're doing yourself, you've got my number. Thanks for your time.
referral_close.note: Leave on a warm note. She may not be the buyer but she could be an internal champion later. Send her a follow-up text with your name and a thank you.

referral_close_warm.label: CLOSE — THEY'LL PASS IT ALONG
referral_close_warm.say: That'd be awesome — honestly even better coming from you than from a cold call. If it helps, I can shoot you a quick email with a one-pager you can forward. That way it's not just 'hey some guy called.' Would hana@keysrealestate.com be the best place to send it?
referral_close_warm.note: Turn her into a warm intro. Give her something easy to forward. Confirm the email address and follow up within the hour.

branches.label: I'll just tell them to expect your call

email_close_referral.label: EMAIL CLOSE — REFERRAL FORWARD
email_close_referral.say: Perfect — I'll have that in your inbox in the next hour. Really appreciate you taking my call, Hana. Enjoy the rest of your day.
email_close_referral.note: Send the email within 30 minutes. Make it easy for her to forward — short, clear, with one specific value prop. Follow up in 3 days if you haven't heard from the referred contact.

referral_who.label: THEY NEED TO CHECK WITH SOMEONE
referral_who.say: Of course — who would that be? I can put together something specific for them so it's not just a generic pitch landing in their inbox.
referral_who.note: Find out who the decision-maker is. This is your path to Claude Gardner or Will Langley or someone else with budget authority.

branches.label: Let me talk to them first and get back to you

book_followup.label: BOOK A FOLLOW-UP
book_followup.say: Totally — take your time. When would be a good day for me to circle back so I'm not just guessing? How about I try you Thursday?
book_followup.note: Pin down a specific day. Don't leave it open-ended or you'll never reconnect.

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next Tuesday and Wednesday pulled up — does morning or afternoon work better for you? It'll be 15 minutes max, super casual.
book_meeting.note: Give two days and let them pick. Lock the time NOW on this call. Don't say 'I'll send you a link to schedule' — that's a dead end.

branches.label: Let me check my calendar and get back to you

confirm_meeting.label: CONFIRM THE MEETING
confirm_meeting.say: Perfect — I'll send you a calendar invite right now to hana@keysrealestate.com. You'll get it in the next couple minutes. Really appreciate you taking my call, Hana. Talk soon.
confirm_meeting.note: Send the invite IMMEDIATELY after hanging up. Use her known email. Stop selling — the meeting is booked. Don't add anything else.

pin_down_meeting.label: PIN DOWN THE MEETING
pin_down_meeting.say: No worries — how about I tentatively put something on your calendar for Wednesday at 11 and if it doesn't work you just let me know and we'll move it? That way it doesn't fall through the cracks for either of us.
pin_down_meeting.note: Don't let them go without a placeholder. A tentative invite is way better than 'I'll get back to you' which almost never happens.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair. One quick question before I do — what would be most useful to include? Like would you rather see what it looks like plugged into Guesty specifically, or more of a general overview of what we're catching for other PMs in the Keys?
send_email.note: Accept the email request but ask one question to tailor it. This also keeps the conversation going and shows you'll send something relevant, not spam.

email_close.label: CLOSE WITH EMAIL COMMITMENT
email_close.say: Got it — I'll send that over today to hana@keysrealestate.com. I'll include a couple time slots in case you want to hop on a quick call after you've looked through it. Appreciate your time, Hana.
email_close.note: Confirm the email address out loud. Include two specific time slots in the email. Follow up with a call 2-3 days later if no response.

graceful_end_with_hook.label: GRACEFUL END WITH HOOK
graceful_end_with_hook.say: Totally understand. If anything changes — especially heading into peak season when turnovers really ramp up — I'm easy to find. Appreciate your time, Hana. Enjoy the island life out there.
graceful_end_with_hook.note: Plant the seasonal seed. Peak season in Key West means more turnovers, more volume, more chances for things to slip. She'll remember this when it gets hectic. Don't burn the bridge.

graceful_end.label: GRACEFUL END
graceful_end.say: Totally get it. Appreciate your time, Hana. If anything ever comes up, you've got my number. Take care.
graceful_end.note: Short, warm, done. Don't linger. Don't pitch one more time. Just close it out respectfully.

confirm_and_close.label: CONFIRM AND CLOSE
confirm_and_close.say: Perfect. I'll shoot you a quick text right now so you've got my number. Talk to you then, Hana. Appreciate it.
confirm_and_close.note: Send the text immediately after hanging up. Keep it short: 'Hey Hana, it's Sam from RapidEye. Looking forward to connecting [day].' Nothing more.
